keywords: Site mapping, Important features, Table 1, Relocate sites, Previously drawn map
abstract:
This text describes a method used for creating a "reach map" for a site. A reach map is a visual representation that highlights crucial features of the site, which can be useful for locating and relocating the site in future. In most cases, a previously drawn map will be given to the person conducting the site analysis, often on the back of the sampling sheet.

The necessity of creating a reach map lies in its ability to provide an easily understandable summary of important site features. This can be especially useful when dealing with large or complex sites, as it simplifies the process of relocating the site or sharing information about it with others. By highlighting essential features on a map, critical details are easily identified and communicated, saving time and resources in the long run.

Additionally, using a previously drawn map as a starting point expedites the process by providing an initial framework for the reach map, reducing the time and effort required to create a detailed and accurate representation of the site.

There is no code provided in this text.
